The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.  For example, a structure like this:  File:
  alternate-link: string
  app-data-contents: boolean
  can-comment: boolean
  can-read-revisions: boolean
  capabilities:
    can-add-children: boolean
    can-change-restricted-download: boolean
    can-comment: boolean
    can-copy: boolean
    can-delete: boolean
    can-download: boolean
    can-edit: boolean
    can-list-children: boolean
    can-move-item-into-team-drive: boolean
    can-move-team-drive-item: boolean
    can-read-revisions: boolean
    can-read-team-drive: boolean
    can-remove-children: boolean
    can-rename: boolean
    can-share: boolean
    can-trash: boolean
    can-untrash: boolean
  copyable: boolean
  created-date: string
  default-open-with-link: string
  description: string
  download-url: string
  editable: boolean
  embed-link: string
  etag: string
  explicitly-trashed: boolean
  export-links: { string: string }
  file-extension: string
  file-size: string
  folder-color-rgb: string
  full-file-extension: string
  has-augmented-permissions: boolean
  has-thumbnail: boolean
  head-revision-id: string
  icon-link: string
  id: string
  image-media-metadata:
    aperture: number
    camera-make: string
    camera-model: string
    color-space: string
    date: string
    exposure-bias: number
    exposure-mode: string
    exposure-time: number
    flash-used: boolean
    focal-length: number
    height: integer
    iso-speed: integer
    lens: string
    location:
      altitude: number
      latitude: number
      longitude: number
    max-aperture-value: number
    metering-mode: string
    rotation: integer
    sensor: string
    subject-distance: integer
    white-balance: string
    width: integer
  indexable-text:
    text: string
  is-app-authorized: boolean
  kind: string
  labels:
    hidden: boolean
    modified: boolean
    restricted: boolean
    starred: boolean
    trashed: boolean
    viewed: boolean
  last-modifying-user:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  last-modifying-user-name: string
  last-viewed-by-me-date: string
  marked-viewed-by-me-date: string
  md5-checksum: string
  mime-type: string
  modified-by-me-date: string
  modified-date: string
  open-with-links: { string: string }
  original-filename: string
  owned-by-me: boolean
  owner-names: [string]
  permission-ids: [string]
  quota-bytes-used: string
  self-link: string
  shareable: boolean
  shared: boolean
  shared-with-me-date: string
  sharing-user:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  spaces: [string]
  team-drive-id: string
  thumbnail:
    image: string
    mime-type: string
  thumbnail-link: string
  thumbnail-version: string
  title: string
  trashed-date: string
  trashing-user:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  user-permission:
    additional-roles: [string]
    auth-key: string
    deleted: boolean
    domain: string
    email-address: string
    etag: string
    expiration-date: string
    id: string
    kind: string
    name: string
    photo-link: string
    role: string
    self-link: string
    type: string
    value: string
    with-link: boolean
  version: string
  video-media-metadata:
    duration-millis: string
    height: integer
    width: integer
  web-content-link: string
  web-view-link: string
  writers-can-share: boolean  can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.   -r .    alternate-link=consetetur  A link for opening the file in a relevant Google editor or viewer.    app-data-contents=false  Whether this file is in the Application Data folder.    can-comment=true  Deprecated: use capabilities/canComment.    can-read-revisions=true  Deprecated: use capabilities/canReadRevisions.    capabilities    can-add-children=false  Whether the current user can add children to this folder. This is always false when the item is not a folder.    can-change-restricted-download=true  Whether the current user can change the restricted download label of this file.    can-comment=true  Whether the current user can comment on this file.    can-copy=false  Whether the current user can copy this file. For a Team Drive item, whether the current user can copy non-folder descendants of this item, or this item itself if it is not a folder.    can-delete=true  Whether the current user can delete this file.    can-download=true  Whether the current user can download this file.    can-edit=true  Whether the current user can edit this file.    can-list-children=true  Whether the current user can list the children of this folder. This is always false when the item is not a folder.    can-move-item-into-team-drive=false  Whether the current user can move this item into a Team Drive. If the item is in a Team Drive, this field is equivalent to canMoveTeamDriveItem.    can-move-team-drive-item=false  Whether the current user can move this Team Drive item by changing its parent. Note that a request to change the parent for this item may still fail depending on the new parent that is being added. Only populated for Team Drive files.    can-read-revisions=true  Whether the current user can read the revisions resource of this file. For a Team Drive item, whether revisions of non-folder descendants of this item, or this item itself if it is not a folder, can be read.    can-read-team-drive=true  Whether the current user can read the Team Drive to which this file belongs. Only populated for Team Drive files.    can-remove-children=false  Whether the current user can remove children from this folder. This is always false when the item is not a folder.    can-rename=true  Whether the current user can rename this file.    can-share=true  Whether the current user can modify the sharing settings for this file.    can-trash=true  Whether the current user can move this file to trash.     can-untrash=false   Whether the current user can restore this file from trash.     ..    copyable=false   Deprecated: use capabilities/canCopy.    created-date=ipsum  Create time for this file (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp).    default-open-with-link=et  A link to open this file with the user s default app for this file. Only populated when the drive.apps.readonly scope is used.    description=invidunt  A short description of the file.    download-url=amet.  No description provided.    editable=true  Deprecated: use capabilities/canEdit.    embed-link=dolor  A link for embedding the file.    etag=et  ETag of the file.    explicitly-trashed=true  Whether this file has been explicitly trashed, as opposed to recursively trashed.    export-links=key=sit  Links for exporting Google Docs to specific formats.  the value will be associated with the given  key    file-extension=vero  The final component of fullFileExtension with trailing text that does not appear to be part of the extension removed. This field is only populated for files with content stored in Drive; it is not populated for Google Docs or shortcut files.    file-size=nonumy  The size of the file in bytes. This field is only populated for files with content stored in Drive; it is not populated for Google Docs or shortcut files.    folder-color-rgb=accusam  Folder color as an RGB hex string if the file is a folder. The list of supported colors is available in the folderColorPalette field of the About resource. If an unsupported color is specified, it will be changed to the closest color in the palette. Not populated for Team Drive files.    full-file-extension=est  The full file extension; extracted from the title. May contain multiple concatenated extensions, such as  tar.gz . Removing an extension from the title does not clear this field; however, changing the extension on the title does update this field. This field is only populated for files with content stored in Drive; it is not populated for Google Docs or shortcut files.    has-augmented-permissions=false  Whether any users are granted file access directly on this file. This field is only populated for Team Drive files.    has-thumbnail=false  Whether this file has a thumbnail. This does not indicate whether the requesting app has access to the thumbnail. To check access, look for the presence of the thumbnailLink field.    head-revision-id=vero  The ID of the file s head revision. This field is only populated for files with content stored in Drive; it is not populated for Google Docs or shortcut files.    icon-link=accusam  A link to the file s icon.    id=et  The ID of the file.    image-media-metadata    aperture=0.878586341956  The aperture used to create the photo (f-number).    camera-make=tempor  The make of the camera used to create the photo.    camera-model=ut  The model of the camera used to create the photo.    color-space=kasd  The color space of the photo.    date=diam  The date and time the photo was taken (EXIF format timestamp).    exposure-bias=0.140512968322  The exposure bias of the photo (APEX value).    exposure-mode=diam  The exposure mode used to create the photo.    exposure-time=0.267675979096  The length of the exposure, in seconds.    flash-used=false  Whether a flash was used to create the photo.    focal-length=0.62829110225  The focal length used to create the photo, in millimeters.    height=97  The height of the image in pixels.    iso-speed=41  The ISO speed used to create the photo.    lens=takimata  The lens used to create the photo.    location    altitude=0.429795978163  The altitude stored in the image.    latitude=0.893771754152  The latitude stored in the image.     longitude=0.871020286609   The longitude stored in the image.     ..    max-aperture-value=0.275706771749   The smallest f-number of the lens at the focal length used to create the photo (APEX value).    metering-mode=justo  The metering mode used to create the photo.    rotation=88  The rotation in clockwise degrees from the image s original orientation.    sensor=eos  The type of sensor used to create the photo.    subject-distance=91  The distance to the subject of the photo, in meters.    white-balance=clita  The white balance mode used to create the photo.     width=62   The width of the image in pixels.     ..indexable-text    text=stet   The text to be indexed for this file.     ..    is-app-authorized=true   Whether the file was created or opened by the requesting app.    kind=stet  The type of file. This is always drive#file.    labels    hidden=false  Deprecated.    modified=true  Whether the file has been modified by this user.    restricted=false  Whether viewers and commenters are prevented from downloading, printing, and copying this file.    starred=true  Whether this file is starred by the user.    trashed=true  Whether this file has been trashed. This label applies to all users accessing the file; however, only owners are allowed to see and untrash files.     viewed=true   Whether this file has been viewed by this user.     ..last-modifying-user    display-name=lorem   A plain text displayable name for this user.    email-address=sanctus  The email address of the user.    is-authenticated-user=false  Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.    kind=dolore  This is always drive#user.    permission-id=est  The user s ID as visible in the permissions collection.     picture    url=invidunt   A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.     ...    last-modifying-user-name=accusam   Name of the last user to modify this file.    last-viewed-by-me-date=accusam  Last time this file was viewed by the user (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp).    marked-viewed-by-me-date=invidunt  Deprecated.    md5-checksum=eirmod  An MD5 checksum for the content of this file. This field is only populated for files with content stored in Drive; it is not populated for Google Docs or shortcut files.    mime-type=sit  The MIME type of the file. This is only mutable on update when uploading new content. This field can be left blank, and the mimetype will be determined from the uploaded content s MIME type.    modified-by-me-date=elitr  Last time this file was modified by the user (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp). Note that setting modifiedDate will also update the modifiedByMe date for the user which set the date.    modified-date=amet  Last time this file was modified by anyone (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp). This is only mutable on update when the setModifiedDate parameter is set.    open-with-links=key=ut  A map of the id of each of the user s apps to a link to open this file with that app. Only populated when the drive.apps.readonly scope is used.  the value will be associated with the given  key    original-filename=duo  The original filename of the uploaded content if available, or else the original value of the title field. This is only available for files with binary content in Drive.    owned-by-me=false  Whether the file is owned by the current user. Not populated for Team Drive files.    owner-names=est  Name(s) of the owner(s) of this file. Not populated for Team Drive files.  Each invocation of this argument appends the given value to the array.    permission-ids=et  List of permission IDs for users with access to this file.  Each invocation of this argument appends the given value to the array.    quota-bytes-used=et  The number of quota bytes used by this file.    self-link=clita  A link back to this file.    shareable=true  Deprecated: use capabilities/canShare.    shared=false  Whether the file has been shared. Not populated for Team Drive files.    shared-with-me-date=invidunt  Time at which this file was shared with the user (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp).    sharing-user    display-name=at  A plain text displayable name for this user.    email-address=rebum.  The email address of the user.    is-authenticated-user=true  Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.    kind=ipsum  This is always drive#user.    permission-id=clita  The user s ID as visible in the permissions collection.     picture    url=clita   A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.     ...    spaces=stet   The list of spaces which contain the file. Supported values are  drive ,  appDataFolder  and  photos .  Each invocation of this argument appends the given value to the array.    team-drive-id=ut  ID of the Team Drive the file resides in.    thumbnail    image=et  The URL-safe Base64 encoded bytes of the thumbnail image. It should conform to RFC 4648 section 5.     mime-type=tempor   The MIME type of the thumbnail.     ..    thumbnail-link=sed   A short-lived link to the file s thumbnail. Typically lasts on the order of hours. Only populated when the requesting app can access the file s content.    thumbnail-version=voluptua.  The thumbnail version for use in thumbnail cache invalidation.    title=at  The title of this file. Note that for immutable items such as the top level folders of Team Drives, My Drive root folder, and Application Data folder the title is constant.    trashed-date=dolor  The time that the item was trashed (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp). Only populated for Team Drive files.    trashing-user    display-name=vero  A plain text displayable name for this user.    email-address=erat  The email address of the user.    is-authenticated-user=true  Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.    kind=dolore  This is always drive#user.    permission-id=stet  The user s ID as visible in the permissions collection.     picture    url=et   A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.     ...user-permission    additional-roles=labore   Additional roles for this user. Only commenter is currently allowed, though more may be supported in the future.  Each invocation of this argument appends the given value to the array.    auth-key=amet  Deprecated.    deleted=true  Whether the account associated with this permission has been deleted. This field only pertains to user and group permissions.    domain=dolore  The domain name of the entity this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user, group or domain.    email-address=dolor  The email address of the user or group this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user or group.    etag=ipsum  The ETag of the permission.    expiration-date=et  The time at which this permission will expire (RFC 3339 date-time). Expiration dates have the following restrictions:    They can only be set on user and group permissions   The date must be in the future   The date cannot be more than a year in the future   The date can only be set on drive.permissions.update requests      id=kasd  The ID of the user this permission refers to, and identical to the permissionId in the About and Files resources. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified unless the permission type is anyone, in which case both id and value are ignored.    kind=sed  This is always drive#permission.    name=tempor  The name for this permission.    photo-link=diam  A link to the profile photo, if available.    role=takimata  The primary role for this user. While new values may be supported in the future, the following are currently allowed:    organizer   owner   reader   writer      self-link=lorem  A link back to this permission.    type=dolor  The account type. Allowed values are:    user   group   domain   anyone      value=amet.  The email address or domain name for the entity. This is used during inserts and is not populated in responses. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified unless the permission type is anyone, in which case both id and value are ignored.     with-link=true   Whether the link is required for this permission.     ..    version=sea   A monotonically increasing version number for the file. This reflects every change made to the file on the server, even those not visible to the requesting user.    video-media-metadata    duration-millis=consetetur  The duration of the video in milliseconds.    height=41  The height of the video in pixels.     width=23   The width of the video in pixels.     ..    web-content-link=at   A link for downloading the content of the file in a browser using cookie based authentication. In cases where the content is shared publicly, the content can be downloaded without any credentials.    web-view-link=sanctus  A link only available on public folders for viewing their static web assets (HTML, CSS, JS, etc) via Google Drive s Website Hosting.    writers-can-share=true  Whether writers can share the document with other users. Not populated for Team Drive files.
docs.title: Required Request Value

docs.text: The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:   The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the  .  character. Fields can be nested such as in  -r f.s.o  .  The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with  . , e.g.  -r .s.s  You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify  -r struct.sub_struct=bar .  You can move the cursor one level up by using  .. . Each additional  .  moves it up one additional level. E.g.  ...  would go three levels up.
docs.title: About Cursors

docs.text: This method supports the upload of data, which  requires  all of the following flags to be set:   -u (simple|resumable)  simple  - Upload media all at once.  resumable  - Upload media in a resumable fashion.    -f file  Path to file to upload. It must be seekable.     The following flag  may  be set:    -m mime  the mime type, like 'application/octet-stream', which is the default
docs.title: Required Upload Flags

docs.text:
The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.   -o out  out  specifies the  destination  to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.
  The  destination  may be  -  to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.
docs.title: Optional Output Flags

docs.text:
You may set the following properties to further configure the call. Please note that  -p  is followed by one 
or more key-value-pairs, and is called like this  -p k1=v1 k2=v2  even though the listing below repeats the -p  for completeness.    -p timed-text-language=string   The language of the timed text.     -p timed-text-track-name=string   The timed text track name.     -p modified-date-behavior=string   Determines the behavior in which modifiedDate is updated. This overrides setModifiedDate.     -p ocr=boolean   Whether to attempt OCR on .jpg, .png, .gif, or .pdf uploads.     -p remove-parents=string   Comma-separated list of parent IDs to remove.     -p pinned=boolean   Whether to pin the new revision. A file can have a maximum of 200 pinned revisions.     -p supports-team-drives=boolean   Whether the requesting application supports Team Drives.     -p new-revision=boolean   Whether a blob upload should create a new revision. If false, the blob data in the current head revision is replaced. If true or not set, a new blob is created as head revision, and previous unpinned revisions are preserved for a short period of time. Pinned revisions are stored indefinitely, using additional storage quota, up to a maximum of 200 revisions. For details on how revisions are retained, see the Drive Help Center.     -p ocr-language=string   If ocr is true, hints at the language to use. Valid values are BCP 47 codes.     -p convert=boolean   This parameter is deprecated and has no function.     -p use-content-as-indexable-text=boolean   Whether to use the content as indexable text.     -p set-modified-date=boolean   Whether to set the modified date with the supplied modified date.     -p add-parents=string   Comma-separated list of parent IDs to add.     -p update-viewed-date=boolean   Whether to update the view date after successfully updating the file.
docs.title: Optional Method Properties

docs.text: The following properties can configure any call, and are not specific to this method.    -p alt=string   Data format for the response.     -p fields=string   Selector specifying which fields to include in a partial response.     -p key=string   API key. Your API key identifies your project and provides you with API access, quota, and reports. Required unless you provide an OAuth 2.0 token.     -p oauth-token=string   OAuth 2.0 token for the current user.     -p pretty-print=boolean   Returns response with indentations and line breaks.     -p quota-user=string   Available to use for quota purposes for server-side applications. Can be any arbitrary string assigned to a user, but should not exceed 40 characters. Overrides userIp if both are provided.     -p user-ip=string   IP address of the site where the request originates. Use this if you want to enforce per-user limits.
docs.title: Optional General Properties

docs.text:
Subscribe to changes on a file


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata.readonly


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.photos.readonly


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.readonly




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 files watch ...


Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file in question.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Channel:
  address: string
  expiration: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  params: { string: string }
  payload: boolean
  resource-id: string
  resource-uri: string
  token: string
  type: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    address=sit


The address where notifications are delivered for this channel.






expiration=magna


Date and time of notification channel expiration, expressed as a Unix timestamp, in milliseconds. Optional.






id=amet.


A UUID or similar unique string that identifies this channel.






kind=clita


Identifies this as a notification channel used to watch for changes to a resource. Value: the fixed string 
api#channel
.






params=key=stet


Additional parameters controlling delivery channel behavior. Optional.


the value will be associated with the given 
key






payload=true


A Boolean value to indicate whether payload is wanted. Optional.






resource-id=eirmod


An opaque ID that identifies the resource being watched on this channel. Stable across different API versions.






resource-uri=elitr


A version-specific identifier for the watched resource.






token=gubergren


An arbitrary string delivered to the target address with each notification delivered over this channel. Optional.






type=sit


The type of delivery mechanism used for this channel.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.


As this method supports 
media download
, you may specify the 
-p alt=media
 flag to set the output to be an octet stream of the underlying media. In that case, you will not receive JSON output anymore.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will either be a JSON-encoded structure, or the media file you are downloading.
  The 
destination
 may be 
-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.








Optional Method Properties


You may set the following properties to further configure the call. Please note that 
-p
 is followed by one 
or more key-value-pairs, and is called like this 
-p k1=v1 k2=v2
 even though the listing below repeats the

-p
 for completeness.






-p projection=string




This parameter is deprecated and has no function.








-p revision-id=string




Specifies the Revision ID that should be downloaded. Ignored unless alt=media is specified.








-p update-viewed-date=boolean




Deprecated: Use files.update with modifiedDateBehavior=noChange, updateViewedDate=true and an empty request body.








-p supports-team-drives=boolean




Whether the requesting application supports Team Drives.








-p acknowledge-abuse=boolean




Whether the user is acknowledging the risk of downloading known malware or other abusive files.








Optional General Properties


The following properties can configure any call, and are not specific to this method.






-p alt=string




Data format for the response.








-p fields=string




Selector specifying which fields to include in a partial response.








-p key=string




API key. Your API key identifies your project and provides you with API access, quota, and reports. Required unless you provide an OAuth 2.0 token.








-p oauth-token=string




OAuth 2.0 token for the current user.








-p pretty-print=boolean




Returns response with indentations and line breaks.








-p quota-user=string




Available to use for quota purposes for server-side applications. Can be any arbitrary string assigned to a user, but should not exceed 40 characters. Overrides userIp if both are provided.








-p user-ip=string




IP address of the site where the request originates. Use this if you want to enforce per-user limits.

docs.text:
You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:   https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata.readonly  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.photos.readonly  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.readonly   If unset, the scope for this method defaults to  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive .
You can set the scope for this method like this:  drive2 --scope  scope  files watch ...

docs.text:
The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.  For example, a structure like this:  Channel:
  address: string
  expiration: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  params: { string: string }
  payload: boolean
  resource-id: string
  resource-uri: string
  token: string
  type: string  can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.   -r .    address=sit  The address where notifications are delivered for this channel.    expiration=magna  Date and time of notification channel expiration, expressed as a Unix timestamp, in milliseconds. Optional.    id=amet.  A UUID or similar unique string that identifies this channel.    kind=clita  Identifies this as a notification channel used to watch for changes to a resource. Value: the fixed string  api#channel .    params=key=stet  Additional parameters controlling delivery channel behavior. Optional.  the value will be associated with the given  key    payload=true  A Boolean value to indicate whether payload is wanted. Optional.    resource-id=eirmod  An opaque ID that identifies the resource being watched on this channel. Stable across different API versions.    resource-uri=elitr  A version-specific identifier for the watched resource.    token=gubergren  An arbitrary string delivered to the target address with each notification delivered over this channel. Optional.    type=sit  The type of delivery mechanism used for this channel.
docs.title: Required Request Value

docs.text: The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:   The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the  .  character. Fields can be nested such as in  -r f.s.o  .  The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with  . , e.g.  -r .s.s  You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify  -r struct.sub_struct=bar .  You can move the cursor one level up by using  .. . Each additional  .  moves it up one additional level. E.g.  ...  would go three levels up.
docs.title: About Cursors

docs.text:
The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.  As this method supports  media download , you may specify the  -p alt=media  flag to set the output to be an octet stream of the underlying media. In that case, you will not receive JSON output anymore.   -o out  out  specifies the  destination  to which to write the server's result to.
  It will either be a JSON-encoded structure, or the media file you are downloading.
  The  destination  may be  -  to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

Adds a parent folder for a file.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 parents insert ...


Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID of the file.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


ParentReference:
  id: string
  is-root: boolean
  kind: string
  parent-link: string
  self-link: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    id=et


The ID of the parent.






is-root=false


Whether or not the parent is the root folder.






kind=justo


This is always drive#parentReference.






parent-link=dolore


A link to the parent.






self-link=at


A link back to this reference.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.

 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.

Inserts a permission for a file or Team Drive.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 permissions insert ...


Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file or Team Drive.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Permission:
  additional-roles: [string]
  auth-key: string
  deleted: boolean
  domain: string
  email-address: string
  etag: string
  expiration-date: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  name: string
  photo-link: string
  role: string
  self-link: string
  type: string
  value: string
  with-link: boolean





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    additional-roles=dolor


Additional roles for this user. Only commenter is currently allowed, though more may be supported in the future.


Each invocation of this argument appends the given value to the array.






auth-key=tempor


Deprecated.






deleted=true


Whether the account associated with this permission has been deleted. This field only pertains to user and group permissions.






domain=est


The domain name of the entity this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user, group or domain.






email-address=et


The email address of the user or group this permission refers to. This is an output-only field which is present when the permission type is user or group.






etag=no


The ETag of the permission.






expiration-date=sed


The time at which this permission will expire (RFC 3339 date-time). Expiration dates have the following restrictions:  


They can only be set on user and group permissions 


The date must be in the future 


The date cannot be more than a year in the future 


The date can only be set on drive.permissions.update requests










id=kasd


The ID of the user this permission refers to, and identical to the permissionId in the About and Files resources. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified unless the permission type is anyone, in which case both id and value are ignored.






kind=ipsum


This is always drive#permission.






name=sadipscing


The name for this permission.






photo-link=sea


A link to the profile photo, if available.






role=eos


The primary role for this user. While new values may be supported in the future, the following are currently allowed:  


organizer 


owner 


reader 


writer










self-link=dolor


A link back to this permission.






type=lorem


The account type. Allowed values are:  


user 


group 


domain 


anyone










value=amet


The email address or domain name for the entity. This is used during inserts and is not populated in responses. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified unless the permission type is anyone, in which case both id and value are ignored.






with-link=false


Whether the link is required for this permission.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.

.

The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.

  additional-roles: [string]
  auth-key: string

  expiration-date: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  name: string
  photo-link: string

email-address=tempor

expiration-date=sed


The time at which this permission will expire (RFC 3339 date-time). Expiration dates have the following restrictions:  


They can only be set on user and group permissions 


The date must be in the future 


The date cannot be more than a year in the future 


The date can only be set on drive.permissions.update requests










id=et


The ID of the user this permission refers to, and identical to the permissionId in the About and Files resources. When making a drive.permissions.insert request, exactly one of the id or value fields must be specified unless the permission type is anyone, in which case both id and value are ignored.






kind=rebum.


This is always drive#permission.






name=eos

photo-link=gubergren


A link to the profile photo, if available.






role=dolores

organizer 


owner 


reader 


writer

user 


group 


domain 


anyone

The email address or domain name for the entity. This is used during inserts and is not populated in responses. .

. Each additional

Adds a property to a file, or updates it if it already exists.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.metadata




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 properties insert ...


Required Scalar Argument




file-id
 
(string)


The ID of the file.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Property:
  etag: string
  key: string
  kind: string
  self-link: string
  value: string
  visibility: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    etag=takimata


ETag of the property.






key=dolor


The key of this property.






kind=ipsum


This is always drive#property.






self-link=lorem


The link back to this property.






value=takimata


The value of this property.






visibility=sanctus


The visibility of this property.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.
  The 
destination
 may be 
-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

Required Upload Flags


This method supports the upload of data, which 
requires
 all of the following flags to be set:

simple

resumable

-f file

The following flag 
may

docs.text:
Creates a new reply to the given comment.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 replies insert ...


Required Scalar Arguments




file-id
 
(string)


The ID of the file.






comment-id
 
(string)


The ID of the comment.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


CommentReply:
  author:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  content: string
  created-date: string
  deleted: boolean
  html-content: string
  kind: string
  modified-date: string
  reply-id: string
  verb: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .author    display-name=labore


A plain text displayable name for this user.






email-address=sed


The email address of the user.






is-authenticated-user=true


Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.






kind=duo


This is always drive#user.






permission-id=sit


The user
s ID as visible in the permissions collection.








picture    url=at




A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.








...    content=voluptua.




The plain text content used to create this reply. This is not HTML safe and should only be used as a starting point to make edits to a reply
s content. This field is required on inserts if no verb is specified (resolve/reopen).






created-date=sed


The date when this reply was first created.






deleted=true


Whether this reply has been deleted. If a reply has been deleted the content will be cleared and this will only represent a reply that once existed.






html-content=dolore


HTML formatted content for this reply.






kind=kasd


This is always drive#commentReply.






modified-date=at


The date when this reply was last modified.






reply-id=diam


The ID of the reply.






verb=takimata


The action this reply performed to the parent comment. When creating a new reply this is the action to be perform to the parent comment. Possible values are:  


resolve
 - To resolve a comment. 


reopen
 - To reopen (un-resolve) a comment.












About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.

destination

-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

Updates an existing reply. This method supports patch semantics.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 replies patch ...


Required Scalar Arguments




file-id
 
(string)


The ID of the file.






comment-id
 
(string)


The ID of the comment.






reply-id
 
(string)


The ID of the reply.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


CommentReply:
  author:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  content: string
  created-date: string
  deleted: boolean
  html-content: string
  kind: string
  modified-date: string
  reply-id: string
  verb: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .author    display-name=tempor


A plain text displayable name for this user.






email-address=at


The email address of the user.






is-authenticated-user=false


Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.






kind=et


This is always drive#user.






permission-id=dolores


The user
s ID as visible in the permissions collection.








picture    url=dolores




A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.








...    content=sed




The plain text content used to create this reply. This is not HTML safe and should only be used as a starting point to make edits to a reply
s content. This field is required on inserts if no verb is specified (resolve/reopen).






created-date=sit


The date when this reply was first created.






deleted=false


Whether this reply has been deleted. If a reply has been deleted the content will be cleared and this will only represent a reply that once existed.






html-content=sea


HTML formatted content for this reply.






kind=est


This is always drive#commentReply.






modified-date=invidunt


The date when this reply was last modified.






reply-id=invidunt


The ID of the reply.






verb=ipsum


The action this reply performed to the parent comment. When creating a new reply this is the action to be perform to the parent comment. Possible values are:  


resolve
 - To resolve a comment. 


reopen
 - To reopen (un-resolve) a comment.












About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.
  The 
destination
 may be 
-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

The following properties can configure any call, and are not specific to this method.






-p alt=string




Data format for the response.








-p fields=string




Selector specifying which fields to include in a partial response.








-p key=string




API key. Your API key identifies your project and provides you with API access, quota, and reports. Required unless you provide an OAuth 2.0 token.








-p oauth-token=string




OAuth 2.0 token for the current user.

Returns response with indentations and line breaks.

Available to use for quota purposes for server-side applications. Can be any arbitrary string assigned to a user, but should not exceed 40 characters. Overrides userIp if both are provided.

Updates a revision. This method supports patch semantics.


Scopes


You will need authorization for at least one of the following scopes to make a valid call:




https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.appdata


https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive.file




If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 revisions patch ...


Required Scalar Arguments




file-id
 
(string)


The ID for the file.






revision-id
 
(string)


The ID for the revision.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


Revision:
  download-url: string
  etag: string
  export-links: { string: string }
  file-size: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  last-modifying-user:
    display-name: string
    email-address: string
    is-authenticated-user: boolean
    kind: string
    permission-id: string
    picture:
      url: string
  last-modifying-user-name: string
  md5-checksum: string
  mime-type: string
  modified-date: string
  original-filename: string
  pinned: boolean
  publish-auto: boolean
  published: boolean
  published-link: string
  published-outside-domain: boolean
  self-link: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .    download-url=clita


Short term download URL for the file. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






etag=sit


The ETag of the revision.






export-links=key=invidunt


Links for exporting Google Docs to specific formats.


the value will be associated with the given 
key






file-size=vero


The size of the revision in bytes. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






id=sed


The ID of the revision.






kind=ut


This is always drive#revision.






last-modifying-user    display-name=rebum.


A plain text displayable name for this user.






email-address=stet


The email address of the user.






is-authenticated-user=false


Whether this user is the same as the authenticated user for whom the request was made.






kind=no


This is always drive#user.






permission-id=rebum.


The user
s ID as visible in the permissions collection.








picture    url=gubergren




A URL that points to a profile picture of this user.








...    last-modifying-user-name=sed




Name of the last user to modify this revision.






md5-checksum=accusam


An MD5 checksum for the content of this revision. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






mime-type=gubergren


The MIME type of the revision.






modified-date=invidunt


Last time this revision was modified (formatted RFC 3339 timestamp).






original-filename=diam


The original filename when this revision was created. This will only be populated on files with content stored in Drive.






pinned=false


Whether this revision is pinned to prevent automatic purging. This will only be populated and can only be modified on files with content stored in Drive which are not Google Docs. Revisions can also be pinned when they are created through the drive.files.insert/update/copy by using the pinned query parameter.






publish-auto=false


Whether subsequent revisions will be automatically republished. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






published=true


Whether this revision is published. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






published-link=sed


A link to the published revision.






published-outside-domain=true


Whether this revision is published outside the domain. This is only populated and can only be modified for Google Docs.






self-link=gubergren


A link back to this revision.

The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:

-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.

 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.

docs.text:
Creates a new Team Drive.


Scopes


You will need authorization for the 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
 scope to make a valid call.


If unset, the scope for this method defaults to 
https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive
.
You can set the scope for this method like this: 
drive2 --scope 
scope
 teamdrives insert ...


Required Scalar Argument




request-id
 
(string)


An ID, such as a random UUID, which uniquely identifies this user
s request for idempotent creation of a Team Drive. A repeated request by the same user and with the same request ID will avoid creating duplicates by attempting to create the same Team Drive. If the Team Drive already exists a 409 error will be returned.








Required Request Value


The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.


For example, a structure like this:


TeamDrive:
  background-image-file:
    id: string
    width: number
    x-coordinate: number
    y-coordinate: number
  background-image-link: string
  capabilities:
    can-add-children: boolean
    can-change-team-drive-background: boolean
    can-comment: boolean
    can-copy: boolean
    can-delete-team-drive: boolean
    can-download: boolean
    can-edit: boolean
    can-list-children: boolean
    can-manage-members: boolean
    can-read-revisions: boolean
    can-remove-children: boolean
    can-rename: boolean
    can-rename-team-drive: boolean
    can-share: boolean
  color-rgb: string
  created-date: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  name: string
  theme-id: string





can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.




-r .background-image-file    id=et


The ID of an image file in Drive to use for the background image.






width=0.039936657156


The width of the cropped image in the closed range of 0 to 1. This value represents the width of the cropped image divided by the width of the entire image. The height is computed by applying a width to height aspect ratio of 80 to 9. The resulting image must be at least 1280 pixels wide and 144 pixels high.






x-coordinate=0.882918620137


The X coordinate of the upper left corner of the cropping area in the background image. This is a value in the closed range of 0 to 1. This value represents the horizontal distance from the left side of the entire image to the left side of the cropping area divided by the width of the entire image.








y-coordinate=0.861051794338




The Y coordinate of the upper left corner of the cropping area in the background image. This is a value in the closed range of 0 to 1. This value represents the vertical distance from the top side of the entire image to the top side of the cropping area divided by the height of the entire image.








..    background-image-link=sit




A short-lived link to this Team Drive
s background image.






capabilities    can-add-children=false


Whether the current user can add children to folders in this Team Drive.






can-change-team-drive-background=true


Whether the current user can change the background of this Team Drive.






can-comment=true


Whether the current user can comment on files in this Team Drive.






can-copy=false


Whether the current user can copy files in this Team Drive.






can-delete-team-drive=true


Whether the current user can delete this Team Drive. Attempting to delete the Team Drive may still fail if there are untrashed items inside the Team Drive.






can-download=true


Whether the current user can download files in this Team Drive.






can-edit=false


Whether the current user can edit files in this Team Drive






can-list-children=false


Whether the current user can list the children of folders in this Team Drive.






can-manage-members=false


Whether the current user can add members to this Team Drive or remove them or change their role.






can-read-revisions=true


Whether the current user can read the revisions resource of files in this Team Drive.






can-remove-children=true


Whether the current user can remove children from folders in this Team Drive.






can-rename=true


Whether the current user can rename files or folders in this Team Drive.






can-rename-team-drive=false


Whether the current user can rename this Team Drive.








can-share=true




Whether the current user can share files or folders in this Team Drive.








..    color-rgb=amet.




The color of this Team Drive as an RGB hex string. It can only be set on a drive.teamdrives.update request that does not set themeId.






created-date=clita


The time at which the Team Drive was created (RFC 3339 date-time).






id=sed


The ID of this Team Drive which is also the ID of the top level folder for this Team Drive.






kind=nonumy


This is always drive#teamDrive






name=sanctus


The name of this Team Drive.






theme-id=consetetur


The ID of the theme from which the background image and color will be set. The set of possible teamDriveThemes can be retrieved from a drive.about.get response. When not specified on a drive.teamdrives.insert request, a random theme is chosen from which the background image and color are set. This is a write-only field; it can only be set on requests that don
t set colorRgb or backgroundImageFile.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.

out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.
  The 
destination

-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

The ID of this Team Drive which is also the ID of the top level folder for this Team Drive.






kind=amet


This is always drive#teamDrive






name=eirmod


The name of this Team Drive.






theme-id=sit


The ID of the theme from which the background image and color will be set. The set of possible teamDriveThemes can be retrieved from a drive.about.get response. When not specified on a drive.teamdrives.insert request, a random theme is chosen from which the background image and color are set. This is a write-only field; it can only be set on requests that don
t set colorRgb or backgroundImageFile.








About Cursors


The cursor position is key to comfortably set complex nested structures. The following rules apply:




The cursor position is always set relative to the current one, unless the field name starts with the 
.
 character. Fields can be nested such as in 
-r f.s.o
 .


The cursor position is set relative to the top-level structure if it starts with 
.
, e.g. 
-r .s.s


You can also set nested fields without setting the cursor explicitly. For example, to set a value relative to the current cursor position, you would specify 
-r struct.sub_struct=bar
.


You can move the cursor one level up by using 
..
. Each additional 
.
 moves it up one additional level. E.g. 
...
 would go three levels up.




Optional Output Flags


The method's return value a JSON encoded structure, which will be written to standard output by default.




-o out


out
 specifies the 
destination
 to which to write the server's result to.
  It will be a JSON-encoded structure.
  The 
destination
 may be 
-
 to indicate standard output, or a filepath that is to contain the received bytes.
  If unset, it defaults to standard output.

docs.title: Update

docs.text:
You will need authorization for the  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive  scope to make a valid call.  If unset, the scope for this method defaults to  https://www.googleapis.com/auth/drive .
You can set the scope for this method like this:  drive2 --scope  scope  teamdrives update ...
docs.title: Scopes

docs.text: team-drive-id   (string)  The ID of the Team Drive
docs.title: Required Scalar Argument

docs.text:
The request value is a data-structure with various fields. Each field may be a simple scalar or another data-structure.
In the latter case it is advised to set the field-cursor to the data-structure's field to specify values more concisely.  For example, a structure like this:  TeamDrive:
  background-image-file:
    id: string
    width: number
    x-coordinate: number
    y-coordinate: number
  background-image-link: string
  capabilities:
    can-add-children: boolean
    can-change-team-drive-background: boolean
    can-comment: boolean
    can-copy: boolean
    can-delete-team-drive: boolean
    can-download: boolean
    can-edit: boolean
    can-list-children: boolean
    can-manage-members: boolean
    can-read-revisions: boolean
    can-remove-children: boolean
    can-rename: boolean
    can-rename-team-drive: boolean
    can-share: boolean
  color-rgb: string
  created-date: string
  id: string
  kind: string
  name: string
  theme-id: string  can be set completely with the following arguments which are assumed to be executed in the given order. Note how the cursor position is adjusted to the respective structures, allowing simple field names to be used most of the time.   -r .background-image-file    id=sit  The ID of an image file in Drive to use for the background image.    width=0.0714693278229  The width of the cropped image in the closed range of 0 to 1. This value represents the width of the cropped image divided by the width of the entire image. The height is computed by applying a width to height aspect ratio of 80 to 9. The resulting image must be at least 1280 pixels wide and 144 pixels high.    x-coordinate=0.367378395057  The X coordinate of the upper left corner of the cropping area in the background image. This is a value in the closed range of 0 to 1. This value represents the horizontal distance from the left side of the entire image to the left side of the cropping area divided by the width of the entire image.     y-coordinate=0.00516717067724   The Y coordinate of the upper left corner of the cropping area in the background image. This is a value in the closed range of 0 to 1. This value represents the vertical distance from the top side of the entire image to the top side of the cropping area divided by the height of the entire image.     ..    background-image-link=gubergren   A short-lived link to this Team Drive s background image.    capabilities    can-add-children=false  Whether the current user can add children to folders in this Team Drive.    can-change-team-drive-background=true  Whether the current user can change the background of this Team Drive.    can-comment=false  Whether the current user can comment on files in this Team Drive.    can-copy=false  Whether the current user can copy files in this Team Drive.    can-delete-team-drive=false  Whether the current user can delete this Team Drive. Attempting to delete the Team Drive may still fail if there are untrashed items inside the Team Drive.    can-download=true  Whether the current user can download files in this Team Drive.    can-edit=false  Whether the current user can edit files in this Team Drive    can-list-children=true  Whether the current user can list the children of folders in this Team Drive.    can-manage-members=false  Whether the current user can add members to this Team Drive or remove them or change their role.    can-read-revisions=false  Whether the current user can read the revisions resource of files in this Team Drive.    can-remove-children=false  Whether the current user can remove children from folders in this Team Drive.    can-rename=true  Whether the current user can rename files or folders in this Team Drive.    can-rename-team-drive=true  Whether the current user can rename this Team Drive.     can-share=false   Whether the current user can share files or folders in this Team Drive.     ..    color-rgb=est   The color of this Team Drive as an RGB hex string. It can only be set on a drive.teamdrives.update request that does not set themeId.    created-date=diam  The time at which the Team Drive was created (RFC 3339 date-time).    id=sit  The ID of this Team Drive which is also the ID of the top level folder for this Team Drive.    kind=amet  This is always drive#teamDrive    name=eirmod  The name of this Team Drive.    theme-id=sit  The ID of the theme from which the background image and color will be set. The set of possible teamDriveThemes can be retrieved from a drive.about.get response. When not specified on a drive.teamdrives.insert request, a random theme is chosen from which the background image and color are set. This is a write-only field; it can only be set on requests that don t set colorRgb or backgroundImageFile.
